captions.text:
JAMES GRIME: We love
pi, of course.
Everyone loves pi.

But one of my favorite
pi facts is--
and I think it's fun.

You only need 39 digits of pi
to be able to measure the

circumference of the observable
universe within the
width of one hydrogen atom.
And that's all you need.

Shall we write out
the 39 digits?
So the 39 digits of pi.
It's 3 point--

now, 3 counts as one
of the digits.
So it's now 38 decimal places.

Let's do the 38 decimal
places--

-He didn't memorize
that, everyone.
There you go.

Show them what you did,
just in case.

JAMES GRIME: Wolfram Alpha
app, never leave
home without it.

-You're not a pi memorizer,
James.
JAMES GRIME: No, I'm not.

And that's another thing
altogether, people that

memorize this pi figure to a
massive amount of digits.

But people who calculate it
using computers, have

calculated it to, currently,
10 trillion digits of pi.
-Go on then.
Let's do it.
JAMES GRIME: OK.
So that would be all you need.
And that's overkill as it is.

Because that's all you need to
measure the circumference of
the observable universe.

So the observable universe is
the distance that light has
traveled since the big bang.

And if you say travelled in a
big sphere, in a big bubble,

then if you measured the
distance around it, we'd have

the circumference
of the universe.

And we would need pi to work
out that circumference.

And we could be as accurate as
a hydrogen atom, if we used
just 39 digits of pi.

We don't need to use the whole
thing, of course, which goes
on forever.

So in fact, and in practical
day-to-day use in engineering

and real life, you would only
need a handful of digits of pi

to have an accuracy that would
be suitable for anything that
you need to do.

So Wolfram Alpha told me that
the diameter of the universe

was 8.8 times 10 to
the 26 meters.

So that's the diameter of
the observable universe.

If you want to work out the
circumference, then
we times it by pi.

So the circumference would
be pi times the diameter.

What's the difference when I
take away my truncated pi?

What I mean is, what if I took
away my pi with 39 digits--
I've called it pi 39--

and did the same thing
times my d?

So that's the real circumference
of the universe,
take away my approximation.
What's the difference?

If I do that, what I got was
actually around about 2.5

times 10 to the minus
12 meters.
So that's how accurate.

That's the difference between
my approximation
and the real value.
That's how accurate it is.

And a hydrogen atom that Wolfram
Alpha told me had a

diameter of about 2.5 times
10 to minus 11 meters.

So in fact, this is
more accurate.

This is more accurate than
a hydrogen atom.

So why do we calculate pi
to 10 trillion digits?

These days, it's a way to
test our computers, our

supercomputers and
our algorithms.

It's a way to test them to
see how good they are.

That's why computer scientists
are interested in
this sort of thing.

Mathematicians have tried to do
this for thousands of years
out of curiosity.
So it started with Archimedes.

He tried to get an accurate
idea of pi about 250 BC.

He didn't have decimals
in those days.
He had to use fractions.
But he tried to work it out.

Then in the 17th century,
there was a Dutch

mathematician called-- now I'll
probably Anglicize his
Dutch name.
And I apologize.

He was called Ludolph
van Ceulen.

And his life's work was working
out the digits of pi.

And by the end of his life,
he had worked out
35 digits of pi.

And they're on his tombstone,
which is kind of cool.
It's kind of neat.

We skip on to the
19th century.

There was a guy who had about
707 digits of pi.

This was the authoritative
example of pi for over 100
years, until 1945.
And they found a mistake.
I know, shock.
They found a mistake.

And the last 180 digits
were wrong.

Because somewhere along in his
calculations, somewhere around

the 500th decimal point,
he had made a mistake.

And from that point on,
everything else was wrong.
What a disaster.

Fortunately, we were able to use
computers by this point.

So in 1949, ENIAC, the American
computer, was able to
calculate pi to 2000 digits.

So suddenly, it just exploded
after that.

Once we've got computers,
it just exploded.

We had more and more
digits of pi.

And now, we've got 10 trillion
digits of pi.

title: Pi and the size of the Universe - Numberphile

comments.author: Neel Modi

comments.text:
+Daniel Stone See 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_that_%CF%80_is_irrational

The fact that the decimals go on forever without repeating is not actually 
all that special, though. The same is true for √2, √3, √5, √6, √7, √8, 
√10... And in fact, the exact length of any object in inch, the exact mass 
of any object in kilograms*, one's exact age in seconds, any continuous 
variable, those would all have infinite non-repeating decimals, too. 
Literally every object around you. We just never notice because we always 
work with approximations. And it would be pointless to be infinitely 
precise, because at the nano and the quantum level everything is ever 
fluctuating.

* except for the actual international prototype kilogram, because the 
kilogram is technically defined as being the mass of that object. So its 
mass, and its alone, is by definition 1.0000000000... (into infinity) 
kilograms.
comments.author: Raizin

very interesting to try to demonstrate something extremely precise - the 
size of the atom of hydrogen - with a first postulate that has nothing 
precise - the size of the Universe. This last "measure" is just an idea, 
nothing more, and contains a lot of uncertainty and other subsequent very 
controversial postulates. For example Dr. Grime seems to consider with care 
we are at the center of the Universe, but not a lot of physicists believe 
in that.﻿

comments.author: TheRhinehart86

comments.text:
I don't know how they manage to work out the large amounts of decimals they 
calculate with computers, but by far the most popular way to do it 
centuries ago was by making regular polygons around a circle, with its 
vertexs actually touching it, and with as many sides as they could manage 
to draw. Another similar polygon was made similarly, in the inside of the 
circle. Therefore, they could state that the perimeter of the 
circumference, which was 2*Pi (if it was diametre 1), was between the two 
perimetres of both polygons.

comments.author: Arya Kataria

comments.text:
The 40th digit is 7, so you round 19 to 20, which is more accurate than 
dropping everything after 19.  You need that accuracy to obtain the 
precision of a hydrogen atom.  And for the same reason, you must keep the 
zero at the end of the string to distinguish the number from those ending 
in 21, 22, 23 and 24, which are increasingly less accurate.  Rounding. 
 Sometimes it's important.

comments.author: Holy Mayonnaisey

comments.text:
I don't really get the hype of Pi. Sure, it is a constant and somehow 
looked upon as a very cool thing, but what about Tau? Tau has been widely 
used in the mathematics before Pi, and is by far the more usable of them 
both. Pi is only used because we somehow think it is non replaceable.﻿
comments.author: Niklas Stenhall

comments.text: Pi hired a better Public Relations Team.
comments.author: Msb Hend

comments.text:
The significance of Pi and Tau from a numerical perspective is identical, 
since they basically represent the same thing. They are both transcendental 
numbers, both derived from geometry, and both actually represent the exact 
same geometry. Tau is just twice Pi.

Pi, however, unlike Tau, has more justification in Calculus. The roots of 
any function satisfying y''+y=0 are distanced exactly Pi from each other. 
That would be half Tau. There are other similar such results. Once you get 
to Calculus, Pi just makes more sense.
comments.author: Saar Korren

comments.text: This channel has explored the Pi vs. Tau question several times.
comments.author: Kevin VanOrd

comments.text: I believe Numberphile already did a video about Tau vs Pi.
comments.author: ascalon132

comments.text:
Pi is easy to know why exists. You want to know what is the circunference 
of a circle? Or its area? That's why pi is here!
Try to do the same thing with Tau, or euler, and you see that's hard.

PS: I completely agree with you. Pi is overrated. But I'm just explaining 
the reason why pi is famous, whilst another constants aren't known.
PS2: Sorry if bad english. Not my first language.

comments.text: what's the point of using the 0 at the end?﻿
comments.author: Russell Chase

comments.text:
+Russell Chase the point of using the zero at the end is to satisfy his 
statement that he can measure the circumference of the universe to within 
the width of a hydrogen atom. Without that last zero, his accuracy/error is 
10 times greater (so he'd theoretically only be within 10 H atoms.) Agreed 
that it doesn't change the "answer" but it does change the "error".
comments.author: David Medberry

comments.text:
+Greg Gaven Except when they're using 40 sig figs, the last 0 becomes 
pretty pointless to write out. Haha xD
comments.author: Orionar Ranoiro

comments.text: +Greg Gaven Gotta love significant figures.
comments.author: BChart3

comments.text:
+Greg Gaven What you say is true. However in this video the premise is that 
only 39 digits of Pi are need to calculate the observable universe to the 
width of a hydrogen atom. The number of significant digits does not play a 
part in the demonstration. 

The 37th, 38th, 39th, 40th and 41st digits of Pi are 41971 (not rounded). 
Pi rounded to the 39th digit is then 3.1415....420. Pi rounded to the 38th 
digit is 3.1415....42. These are equivalent values. Only 38 digits are 
needed (assuming rounding, as it was assumed in this video).
comments.author: Scott Dixon

comments.text:
In the video, they said that he rounded up. Furthermore, when measuring 
things, there is uncertainty to the accuracy of the measurement. For 
example, 3 litres is a lot different than 3.000 litres. So the zero isn't 
pointless.

comments.author: Elias Ednie

comments.text:
Actually, it is important to note that Pi being infinite does not mean it 
must contain every combination (even non-repeating is insufficient) as, for 
example (this is almost certainly not the case), Pi could contain no 7's 
after, say, the 123,903,912,946,523,182,097th digit, and thus would be 
unable to contain all numbers of all lengths.
Makes you wonder if anyone has proved that it does contain every possible 
combination of digits...

comments.text:
Pi is the relationship between a circle's diameter and its circumference.
Even taking away the fancy algorithms people have made to calculate the 
digits of pi, If you can perfectly measure a circle's diameter and 
circumference, calculating pi would just be a simple division problem.

comments.author: ElderFrog

comments.text:
The number π has so many digits because its decimals go on forever. It is 
possible for a non-terminating decimal to be rational. For example, the 
number ⅓ (0.333333...) has so many digits in the form of a non-terminating 
decimal, but is rational. Remember, all irrational numbers are 
non-terminating decimals; but not all non-terminating decimals are 
irrational.

comments.text:
True, but just like the Planck length has yet to cooperate with the concept 
of a singularity (e.g. that of a black hole or the state of the universe at 
the moment of the Big Bang), Planck time doesn't "work" when singularities 
are involved. But at every other time and location in existence, I agree: 
Planck length, time, etc. are the lowest limit, and the universe itself is 
the upper limit. Everything else is relative! :)

I didn't say it was wrong; in fact, I know of the reasoning behind it and 
its truth in the current state of the universe. One should acknowledge the 
one problem with the idea of Planck time that is yet to be solved, though: 
the time just after the big bang occurred. According to modern string 
theory and M theory, at that moment, the universe expanded from a single 
string wrapped maximally into a (possibly Calabi-Yau) space the size of the 
Plank length into the size of a galaxy within a second!!!
